newsitem.title: USA: CBOT official sees TOPS launch with CME in Q1 1997. [CORRECTED 24/10]
newsitem.headline: CBOT official sees TOPS launch with CME in Q1 1997. [CORRECTED 24/10]

text.p: (In October 23 CHICAGO item headlined "CBOT official sees TOPS launch with CME in Q1 1997" please read in first paragraph ... Trade Order Processing System ... instead of ... Total Order Processing System. Please read also that launch is of a "common switch," not entire TOPS system, and that TOPS was developed by the CME, not by the exchanges jointly.)

The Chicago Board of Trade and Chicago Mercantile Exchange will implement a "common switch" for their Trade Order Processing System (TOPS) in the first quarter of 1997, Donald Karmizan, CBOT senior vice president of technology, said.
The common switch will allow orders to be routed to floors of both exchanges from a variety of trading systems.

"Our plan is to create a user-friendly TOPS route interface," Karmizan told the Futures Industry Association annual conference here on Wednesday. "We are targeting the first quarter of 1997 to deliver that capability."

He said TOPS would be flexible enough to meet future demands in both the open outcry and electronic trading environments. A CME spokeswoman said TOPS was developed by the CME and licensed to the CBOT in 1993.
Karmizan said that while CBOT's Project A and CME's GLOBEX electronic trading systems were fairly successful, both exchanges were looking at alternative trading systems as well.

"The (CBOT and CME) are looking at different systems potentially in the future that will give them greater electronic trading capabilities to meet the demands of the marketplace," Karmizan said without elaborating.

He also said electronic order routing to the CBOT's trading floor would be used in conjunction with the hand-held audit trade recording device to meet the 90 percent accuracy standard mandated by Congress.
"Eventually, we see the hand-held device being expanded to deal with order delivery capabilities on the floor," Karmizan said.
Both the CBOT and CME are still testing hand-held audit trail devices.
Donald Serpico, CME executive vice president of operations, said the CME was looking at various off-the-shelf technologies for use in the devices.

"Basically, we (CME) are doing this (testing audit devices) for operational efficiency, and if it helps with the accuracy, fantastic," Serpico added. -Derivatives desk 312-408-8750;E-mail derivatives@reuters.com
